values:
Well better late than never I suppose.  An update on my folks :)

<lj-cut text="More . . .">
Dad was out of the hospital as of last Monday.  Still has a bit of subcutaneous bruising on his arms and such, and energy levels are not back full but are definitely much better than he was.  He obtained a rental car Thursday and has been ambling around town just fine.  He and I have even swapped emails on Monopoly, one of his old favorite games.  Seems like things are only on the upswing for him.  He did have a minor scare last Wednesday morning, as he had some growing numbness in his cheek, leg, and so forth - all on his left side.  He called out EMS but it turned out to be nothing more than likely nerve damage from the accident itself - the paramedics assured him his blood pressure was indeed elevated (likely due to the stress of, say, calling an ambulance for yourself) but was not NEARLY high enough to be an indicator of a stroke or other such catastrophic issues.

Mom is still in the hosptal - but was downgraded to a regular room last Thursday/Friday.  Since then she has actually been up and around on a walker as well as sitting up.  She was taken off of solid food late last week due to severe constipation, but that is starting to clear up (and was likely caused by the morphine and other painkillers she was on for the first several days) and last night her dinner was supposed to have soft food in it.  I didn't get a chance to talk to her last night (family night and so forth), hopefully I'll get to do so today sometime.  Her spleen is still fine, although there is a pending biopsy for her thyroid - while the folks were scanning this that and the other they came across some suspicious looking nodes on it.

She got two units of blood the other day due to dropping blood counts - likely due to the lack of overall nutrition and sedentary activity lately.  The ribs are healing, and her lung capacity is still ok.  Mentally she's just getting better and better - more and more talkative and energetic, so seems like improvements are continuous and large.

I'd also like to express my appreciation for all those who've checked in on me during this time :) the support has been awesome and Dawn and I are incredibly grateful for it!
</lj-cut>

So sometime Saturday night something happened that hasn't happened in a very, very long time.

My folks were in a traffic accident.  Hit from the passenger side by a cab as my Dad crossed an intersection.  According to the police, he ran a red light.  That's a surprise all by itself, since Dad generally doesn't make traffic mistakes - but then everyone misses things from time to time.

<lj-cut text="Read More...">
The cab driver was ok - but that figures, given the physics of the situation.  GG momentum.

My folks - not ok, at least, not entirely.  Dad suffered from fluid on a lung, and one or two fractured ribs, plus a small cut on his face (solved by a single stitch).  Mom fared worse: at last count, several broken ribs on both sides, a collapsed lung, a bleeding spleen, and I believe some broken bones in her left hand.  On top of that, there has been mention of cracks and/or fractures in her pelvis

Things have improved at this point: Dad was discharged yesterday, Mom is still in the hospital and we've yet to have the chance to talk to a doctor about her situation.  However, I found out today that they are rolling her from side to side to give her an in-bed sponge bath, so that would rule out in my mind any significant spinal issues, as well as no severe pelvic or hip fractures.  I saw her wiggle her toes today, which was also obviously comforting.  Her lung has re-inflated at least somewhat, and the spleen was cauterized late Sunday.  For someone who was life-flighted into the emergency room she seems to be doing very well.

On top of all this their glasses were no where to be found in the hospital - so since of them both have pretty bad vision, they were effectively blind to top it all off.  I made some effort yesterday to try to get access to the car itself in the hopes of looking through it and retrieving at least some lens fragments, assuming we could then get some new temporary glasses made for them, but the amount of legal wrangling necessary for a non-bank non-lien holder to get acess to a car not owned by them was too much to accomplish on a holiday.  Even with paper in hand, the notary hunt was unsuccessful, and at the end of the day no progress was made.

However, with Dad getting discharged yesterday, he himself has all the power necessary to access his car, and we went down to the storage lot today.  The car has got to be totalled - the gear box dropped, which leads me to assume the engine probably did as well.  The right rear door is a hunk of twisted metal, the frame compressed far enough in to completely expose the right rear tire.  The right front door was detached.  The floor of the trunk was buckled.  In fact the only part of the car that looked intact was the left side body panels, and potentially the front and rear axles. This site was not an easy one for Dad to see, but my presence and Alasen's, I think, helped keep things in perspective for him.

Then miracles of miracles:  not only were we able to recover his phone, a tape measure, 2 cases of CD's, and a variety of other personal items - he found his prescription sunglasses, his regular glasses - and then I spotted another pair of glasses on the floorboard right between the driver seat and the door.  Mom's glasses, intact, with the clip-on sunglass lenses attached.  Earpieces munged to hell, true, but with a little tweaking they were still wearable.  My parents could see again.  This one discovery today was probably the high point of progress thus far.

We took Dad out to dinner tonight, the unspoken commentary of "gee, wish Mom could join us too" was with us as we ate, but we made the best as we could.  Dad and I had steak and shrimp, never a bad thing.  

I took him in to see Mom today, and Mom was much more active and vocal and aware than she was on Sunday.  I hadn't seen her since then.  Dawn and Alasen haven't seen her at all - Mom has horrible allergies to our cats and so she asked that they not come in - the thought of sneezing with all her ribs busted and lung issues was really scaring her.  As it was I never got very close to her on Sunday and today I remained across the room as far as possible for her comfort.  Dad has the "privacy passcode" now, so I'm hopeful he'll be able to get some real information tomorrow.

We are staying at a local Holiday Inn for one more night (tonight), and then based on how things go tomorrow (and what the word is on Mom's health) we'll either be heading back to Austin or moving into a likely cheaper hotel out in the Katy area (we're in the downtown River Oaks area of Houston at the moment - and while we were lucky and got a decent rate due to the holiday the rate is jumping almost double tomorrow night.  Since Dad has moved back home it's probably better we're a little closer to him anyway - at least until he makes another big step: driving again.  Tonight he said he plans on getting a rental either Thursday or Friday, depending on how he's holding up with the thought of solo driving again.  For my part I'm not terribly comfortable leaving him here without any sort of transportation to get around - but I'd also really like to be back in Austin this coming weekend to celebrate Dawn's 31st Birthday.

So I'll be doing what I've been trying to do since I got here: go one day at a time, hope for the best, and keep on loving.
</lj-cut>

I forgot I had a friendster account too.

TOO

MUCH

SOCIAL.

So last night Dawn reminded me she had, in fact, sent me an email detailing some form or fashion of actually keeping all my social site networking linked and consistent. Of course, I just barely remember such an email - but it's time to go spelunking for it I do believe :) Meanwhile I've swapped from iJournal to Phoenix since I discovered, in a state of mild panic of course, that yesterday's whopper of a blog could have been lost mid-entry if iJournal or my system had crashed. There is no "save file" option, unlike in Phoenix. Phoenix also has a built-in spellchecker, an item very necessary for a guy like me who'se fingers are generally slower than my mind. Well, as I just found out, it accesses a shared spellchecker called Excalibur, but still. That's mighty useful. . except that it's not, actually, as it's not working. BUT HEY. I can at least save off blogs before posting in case of crises. More news as it happens . . ..

So I've started browsing about for other hobbies - because hey, life's too short to sit on my ass and not spend money. Current things in the pipeline that I'm looking at: Chaotic Pros: Hey it's a TCG, the stuff I just love. . Also features an online component, in which you upload the cards you have and can actually play the game online - thus dramatically upping the number of folks I could actually play with. The gameplay looks fairly straightforward, and consists of using your army of monsters to beat up the other guys army of monsters. Cons: Hey, it's a TCG, noted for being a pain in the ass to collect. The online component is Windows only, of course. It's still in beta, and the jury is still out if they will make a mac version or not. Status: Snagged one of the two starters, have the 2nd on order (takes 2 starters to even try the thing out) Dungeons™ &™ Dragons™ Miniatures™® Pros: Fairly cheap to try it out - just one starter set for $15.00 and bam, two people can play. Dawn and I gave it a whirl - it's really not too bad. Skirmish style, in that you and your "warband" of 3-10 dudes go beat up the other person's warband and/or hold onto "victory areas" for points. Actually was more fun than either of us anticipated, and for my part I wouldn't mind playing it another time or two to get a sense of it. Multiple scenario maps. Cons: Lots of maintenance while playing. You have to keep track of the current health of all your figures on the game board, plus keep track of one-use abilities, and a few other variables. Game has a great deal of detail when it comes to the actual combat, as far as tracking line of sight and the like, which only gets more complicated around corners and when dealing with obstacles. This game is effectively nothing more than a somewhat simplified version of the D&D RPG combat rules - includes cover, area of effect spells, dispersion, invisibility, flanking, and so forth. One of my concerns is that, since this is a collectible game (replete with blind boosters), there are a few specific models out there that are very rare, and thus very expensive, that are required to even have a shot at doing well. Status: I'll be doing some more research on this one. Dawn kinda liked it, but liked it less than I did I believe. There is a possibility Alasen might enjoy it, if she can muster the patience to digest all the detailed rules. Having stuffed a fairly sizeable box full of DreamBlade miniatures that will never be used again (Dawn and I felt the game was crap after I had dropped $80 on some 150 miniatures) we are both somewhat leery of over-investing. The house is not infinite in size, after all. I do however tend to be more of a packrat than I should be, with the concern of "oh but wait, someday I might want to play it again!" Maybe I should just Freecycle the lot (minus a few of the really pretty ones). Warhammer 40,000 Pros: Lots of miniatures to paint, which is a hobby I am interested in picking back up. I've not yet looked at the rules because .. Cons: LOTS of miniatures to paint. One does not play Warhammer with a dozen figures, one plays it with hundreds. Aside from the storage issue and the time investment, that's a crapton of cash. What's more, the game is set up such that the rules change every year or so, requiring ANOTHER purchase of the new rule book - which usually goes for around $80-100. On top of that, Games Workshop is rapidly becoming the unholy combination of Wal-Mart + Microsoft of the miniature gaming world and there is a growing amount of irritation and anger brewing on the part of customers. Warhammer is a game that once you're in you tend to stay in - but it is not very friendly to new players, at all. Status: totally not interested. Vast sum of time + money just to get started, plus continual annual refresher costs, plus various reviews I have read indicating the game is not at all balanced - either play Space Marines or lose. I've not come across a positive review in two days, even after hitting up my buddies over at the Warcraft guild forums I still wander in. Hordes, which is in turn an expansion of WarMachine Pros: Some miniatures to paint, but not nearly so damned many as WarHammer 40K. Rules look fairly straightforward, at least the introduction rules I've been able to read. There is a game night at the local Dragon's Lair where this is played that is reasonably compatible with my schedule. Net cost to start playing is $40 for the "warbox" which has an acceptable warband. Next tier is to buy the full rules book, which can be had for $20 if I stoop to paperback. WarMachines and Hordes play very different as far as flavor but the systems are compatible, leaving me with some nice options for variety. And all the factions are designed to be powerful and balanced against each other. Cons: Still a bit of an investment to get started, altho there is the mitigator that the price for the miniatures themselves is not out of line with just buying any old miniature to paint - so this way I can paint AND play. Storage and transport will become a concern if I get "srs", plus the need to stock up on some physical terrain features will only add to the cost and size. Status: I'm going to head down to Dragon's Lair likely next week and check it out. A fellow there offered to let me borrow one of his 3 armies for a trial run. Other stuffs: I'm getting back into console gaming these days, having started in on Halo I, Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, and a bit of Super Smash Brothers. I am highly looking forward to our new 50" HDTV, rearranging the house, and getting a PS3 for some srsgamez. On top of that I've started my side project of creating a world, from scratch. Currently that's on a mild hold while I figure out what vector based drawing package to use for map making - which will likely just be some .... "borrowed" software. Social networking is getting janky - now that I have accounts on five fucking different social sites of one ilk or another since there is more than one choice, I'm somewhat looking for ways to keep them all linked. Fortunately most of them support importing LiveJournal blogs, but there's also something to be said for just bailing on LJ and scooting over to the newly-Google-owned Blogspot and having it all linked in with my Orkut account which in turn I can probably still import from into Facebook and so forth and so on. Meanwhile myspace is the pain in the ass one - I hate that fucking site, but EVERYONE IS THERE. Gad. And it has zero support for blog importing, so whenever I make an update I have to go over there and link to this one manually. I may try a cut and paste today just to see how it deals with the LJ tags.

Well I have to learn how to use Open Workbench as part of my project management responsibilities - at least for now, until we finally find the bandwidth to investigate other more full-featured project management tools like Primavera. Those among you capable of reading may have noticed that Open Workbench only works on Windows. Apparently because all project managers are stupid enough to use a piece of shit operating system, I don't know. I, however, use a macintosh here at the office. So to continue this lovely kludge attempt I had to install some sortof VMware - and we ended up with VirtualBox and a horked WindowsXP install. The whole thing seems to run ok for the moment, but it was kinda icky seeing that stupid Windows crap on my shiny iMac, I must say :)

Yesterday was the big day :) Posted my Warcraft resignation thread on both guild forums that I am a member of, reminded my charming guild leader that will still be around, added a half-dozen or so folks to my various friend lists on the social sites I passed around, and .. Actually logged into the account management page, and cancelled allllllll four Warcraft accounts :) (two were mine, two were 's). Unfortunately we had all four on the six-month plan (hell, I had been playing for a long time, and that is a cheaper way to do it in those cases), and they do not do a prorate option - so our accounts are going to start falling off in the early August time frame. I'm not really sure I'll log in again - I might bounce my bank toon one last time to make sure I snagged the last set of auctions but that's likely it. I should probably hit the Horde side and let my few friends over there know as well - Grimmaul and Kaos as the very least, fine folks they were. Not that I played Horde much, but still. Mildly cathartic, really :) Meanwhile last night I went out to dinner with a long time friend in from New York. We went down to Ironworks BBQ, which was pretty tasty. She's friended on FaceBook if you, dear reader, happen to be signed up there. OO. David brought in some pastries. He's a guy at work who just brings in excessively tasty crap all the frickin' time. I'm off :)

Man, they just kind of drone on in my head these days, but I thought perhaps I should write them down. I'll probably even stage this writing, so I don't try to do it all at once and then manage to do it poorly. And just to be clear, and as fair as I can: I avoided playing any MMORPG for years - I didn't even participate in MUDs. Finally, Blizzard, one of my favorite gaming companies, came out with one. I was unable to resist any longer :) I played World of Warcraft, avidly, even excessively, for 3 solid years. It was my only real hobby, and I sucked the marrow from its bones. Hundreds of screenshots of my characters progressing, of bosses killed, of friend's characters, of the gorgeous atmospherics, capturing any and all lore-related in game text that I could find, looking forward to my next opportunity to log in and make some progress on whatever character I was most interested in at the moment. I raided Molten Core, parts of Blackwing Lair, Ruins of Ahn'Qiraj, Karazhan, Zul'Aman, Gruul's Lair, made some feeble and ultimately unsuccessful attempts at Magtheridon and Tempest Keep. PVP was not something I gravitated to, but I did have a few Arena matches and played in every PVP environment in the game at the time I was there. I have a 70 druid, 70 warlock, 70 paladin, and 70 hunter, plus a 61 mage, and a whole slew of alts below that - I reached the point of having gotten almost every class to at least 20. Part of me still wants to level the remaining 5 classes to 70 just for the novelty of exploring a different class. Finally one day I realized I just wasn't enjoying the game much anymore. I loved my friends, liked my guildmates and alliance-mates (on the political front, I helped to forge a cross-guild alliance that has lasted almost 2 years at this point - likely a world first in its own right even though nothing had to be killed to accomplish it), went up the ranks to co-leader of a medium-sized successful guild (successful in that it has stayed around with the same core group of folks for almost 3 years with only a few bouts of drama), but I came to realize that the game itself started to become rather boring - I started seeing it not as a world to play in but as a long continuous stream of treadmills to walk, stretching on into infinity. The final straw was taking one of my characters out to a new island that had been added into the game - normally something I would have been TREMENDOUSLY excited about - and seeing all those golden !'s above all those NPC's heads with the hidden stories and cash and faction and loot that they represented .. and I just felt tired. I didn't do a single quest out there, and just flew home and logged out. I saw it only as another pile of shit to shovel, and there was no real draw to do it. I desperately wanted to get my druid her epic flying form, which costs 5,000 gold - but it's been two weeks now and I've just not wanted it bad enough to even log back in to do the daily quests to feed the cash machine. I hit the point of realization that if I ever do go back it will likely be cheaper by then anyway so fuck it. I did get an epic flyer for one of my characters, the warlock - I chose her because a) she was my "main" at the time and b) I wanted to legitimately roll on the super duper rare epic flyer that dropped off a raid boss. A raid boss we ultimately never made it to because there just wasn't enough folks in our community with sufficiently compatible schedules to go make attempts at the place. Right now I'm sitting on 3K gold and no interest in raising more, even though I could do it in a month or less. I do feel twinges of wanting to play - but then a couple days ago when I almost did log back in, I realized I was only choosing it not out of actual desire, but out of boredom. It was easier to log in than to figure out what I actually wanted to do. I ended up reading a book. Ultimately just as non-useful in a life-sense, but - I WANTED to do it, as opposed to just doing it out of habit. (By way of background information: from my perspective, the only real "purpose" to existence is to propagate your specie. It is what we were designed for or evolved for. The rest is largely irrelevant. But - I'm here, and I am conscious. I do things that are pleasureable - and while I am here, I believe in doing as many fun things as I can, and having as many life-experiences as I can, because to not do so is just a waste of potential. Under my reasoning, reading a book or playing a video game are the same - they do nothing to reproduce another human and so are useless. Even if I may learn new skills from the reading, that is still just me finding something to do that I am interested in, and in the long run has no more real net value on the scale of why I exist than staring at the wall for 6 hours a day. I just enjoy one a bit more than the other.) From this experience, I have learned that I really enjoy MMORPG's. Being involved in groups to accomplish tasks, playing in a fictional environment where risk-taking has in-game consequences but no real life impacts, exploring new areas and the like, are really, really fun. So fun I paid Blizzard almost $1000 over 3 years for the opportunity to do so, both alone and with my wife. We even went to Blizzard's first gaming convention, the first Blizzcon, and had a BLAST. But at this point, there are certain key areas of the game that have overwhelmed what fun I have, and have become the walls that block off whatever enjoyment is left for me. I thought it might be a good idea to write them down for others to read - both as a mental exercise for myself, and as an explanation to those who won't be seeing me log in for a good long while, if ever. I might even send it to Blizzard, on the hopes they make take a few suggestions from it for their next MMORPG. I hope to find another game to play with my wife and friends someday, but for now, Warcraft is not it. In no particular order, they are: 1) Lack of Permanence. No matter what you do, where you go, who you meet, quests you finish, bosses that you kill . . . the most you ever will get is a piece of equipment. That's it. Occasionally, you get a key that goes in your keyring. Sometimes, you get a piece of equipment that is so nice, or cool to look at, you will use up a precious bank slot to store it. Of course, no one else in the game can see what is in your bank. And no one else in the game can see your keyring. The only way to publicly display what you have done is to have the right piece of equipment on - and 90% of the time, after a week or three, that piece of equipment is outdated and needs to be trashed. There is no trophy hall, there is no hangings on the wall, nothing, anywhere, that you can show folks in game what your accomplishments are. The best you can do is tell them in a chat window, and hope the believe you. Some may argue "well but there's faction, and you can always go look that up at the armory". Well true, but whoopty-doo. "I totally killed Nightbane in Karazhan", you say. "I'm exalted with the Violet Eye, go check it out", you say. Well, as it turns out, you could just get with a couple buddies and farm the first three mobs in the place every day for 12 hours and get Exalted. You don't even have to see a boss, much less down it, much less down the one that must be summoned at the very end. The only record of what you have done in game is thus entirely limited to what you write down, or what you remember, and neither of those are much to show off to your friends, guildmates, etc. While this is certainly not something critical to the core game mechanic of WoW, not even a little bit, it is a nice feature that I as a player would think is a good thing. It's like actually having a "home" of sorts in game. Even if it's not "ZOMG PLAYER HOUSING", it could be as simple as a set of medals displayed on your cape. However, it's not there. There is no home. The player has zero ways of making any permanent change to any segment of any part of the world environment. All mobs respawn - even the rare ones. All bosses are there waiting for you, again, next time you log in. Any items that you set fire to or destroy as part of a quest just magically reappear about 2 minutes after you are done - there's not even an animation of folks rebuilding it or putting out the fire. And even if there was, if you sat around long enough you'd see it all become just like it was. Most of the quests you ever do, you will likely do again, and again, and again, on every toon you ever roll, ad infinitum. From my vantage point, that means the game is effectively like a glorified TV program, where the player is a largely passive observer who just has to click the pause button on the remote at the right time to skip the commercials, and then hit the rewind button at the end, to watch the program a few more times because it's all that's on. 2) "Skill". There are lots of arguments on this one. Discussions of skill this and skill that rage on the WoW forums from time to time. One side says "ZOMG SKILLZ", the other says "ZOMG EZMODE", and on it goes. Here's my impression, in both of the two categories the player can hope to advance along of the two advancement paths for improving one's armor and weapons (as noted, these are the only things you can ever really "improve"). a) PVP: I was initially very frustrated with PVP in WoW. I come from a first person shooter background, having grown my gaming wings on the likes of Doom ][ and Quake 3 Arena. In these games the major skill requirement is fast reflexes and some hand eye coordination. Later one learns a bit of terrain exploitation and resource control (resources being ammunition and armor - learn the level so you can get them before your opponent does, thus putting them constantly on the defensive). Even with a significant upgrade in your equipment however (max armor, the rocket launcher or equivalent, and so forth), it was still within a reasonable realm of possibility for a decently skilled player without these power-ups to kill you. The pacing is frenetic and spontaneous, the controls instantaneous and responsive, and every single person starts out exactly the same when they "spawn" into the environment. It's up to you to round up better weapons and armor and take the fight to your opponent. So there's my backstory to illustrate where my biases come from in the following discussion. Warcraft's PVP is horribly frustrating, because none of those rules apply: i) Combat is NOT instantaneous - almost every single offensive action you take starts a global cooldown, lasting about 1.5 seconds. During this time all you can do is move. That's it. Some classes may be able to activate certain special abilities - but you are effectively prevented from doing much of anything. Thus, the main skill involved is careful planning of trying to get the other guy to get on his cooldown before you get on yours, so you can take advantage of his lack of ability to do anything. ii) No one EVER starts out equal. Unequal gearing is common, and is the norm. And in Warcraft, gear is everything. In the case of two equally skilled opponents, He Who Has More Purples Wins. This is almost always true. The only time the titan of purple armor is brought down is when he is ganged up on, and even then sometimes that is insufficient. The better your gear, the higher your hit points, the higher your armor, the higher all of your combat stats are, and thus, the more damage you do. So then between two unequally geared opponents, the undergeared one faces a whopping THREE disadvantages: the better geared person has more health, the better geared person does more damage, and the undergeared person TAKES more damage as a percentage of their health, thus further accelerating their demise. And then in the case of equally geared and equally skilled opponents, it boils down to the random chance of who gets the big critical strikes in first, or, more likely, the classic rock/paper/scissors game: some classes are just more likely, because of their innate class abilities, to beat certain classes than others. It can be argued that clever use of the "long cooldown" (i.e. abilities which you can only use once every minute, every five minutes, and so forth) can stem the tide of battle in your favor, but that would be one of the few regions of true skill in this game. iii) There are NO resources to control. The only powerups available on a PVP map are usually defensive in nature, and there are perhaps 3 or 4 total. There is one that affects how fast you run, one that affects how much damage you do, and one that heals you. That's it. None are jawdroppingly awesome, none last for more than a few seconds. While they will make or break certain encounters with the enemy, they are not controllable in any real practical sense. iv) There is NO terrain to exploit (with two caveats). Your damage is always the same, whether you have higher ground, whether or not you are hidden, whether or not you are behind partial cover, whether or not you are airborne, lying down, behind a box, etc. There are no "splash damage" effects caused by reflection of forces off of walls, floors, and ceilings. Terrain can only be exploited in one of two ways: a) a glitch in the terrain map that allows you to cheat by hiding from the enemy in places they cannot easily reach (and such exploitation is considered breaking the rules), and b) by exploiting the fact that most character abilities require a line of sight to the opponent to land your attack. This latter one is another faint shade of "skill" - but only really negatively impacts those classes who deal most of their damage from a range. Melee-oriented classes are unaffected. There is one aspect of Warcraft PVP that is actually rather entertaining and, I would argue, skill based. Teamwork. An organized team of people will have dramatically better luck against a team that has no chain of command and is merely chaotic. This organization can EVEN overcome a gear gap, though I state (without proof, granted) that a team that is poorly geared still stands a good chance of being crushed by a chaotic mass wearing excellent gear. Warcraft PVP quickly becomes a grinding operation. You go PVP for hours and hours, so you can get better gear, so you can go PVP for hours and hours, so you can get better gear, so you can go PVP for hours and hours, so you can get better gear. Perhaps, someday, you MIGHT earn a Title to put in front of your name, and perhaps, if you are very good at exploiting the Arena system and are reasonably competent at hiding behind pillars when facing ranged damage classes and have mastered all your tricky cooldowns, you might just maybe get yourself the fastest mount in the game. So you can fly 10% faster to all those PVP matches. UPDATE: I just read about Blizzard's "Tournament Arena" servers. These will indeed eliminate the gear gap entirely - but instead you get to pay $20 just for the privilege of even entering. So while I will grant that Blizzard has added a component of PVP that will side-step the gear issues, it feels like a tacked on excuse for a solution rather than anything that will actually change the core game mechanic. More at creating a set of "side tournaments" instead of adding something to the game itself. b) PVE: In Warcraft, if you want the top gear you can get from PVE, you raid. Failing that, you do dungeons on heroic mode. You do these things over and over again. A raid is a glorified dungeon that is only doable by 10, 15, or 25 individuals. A dungeon on heroic mode is generally only doable by 5 decently geared and vaguely intelligent individuals. In both cases, you need the proper makeup - certain class roles are REQUIRED for success in these cases. The last thing you can do to get top gear is make it, or have it made for you. So lets sum up these three modes of "play": i) Raiding: Find enough friends and schedule a time, weekly, to do the same dungeon, over and over and over and over and over again, until, some months away, everyone has the nice gear they want from the place. At this point, your gear is of high enough quality that you can then do the next dungeon, over and over and over and over and over again, until, some months away, everyone has the yet nicer gear they want from the place. At this point, your gear is of a higher quality that you can then do the next dungeon, over and over and over . . . . . ii) Heroic Dungeons: Largely the same as raiding, except it takes only 4 friends. You can do them MORE than once a week though (once a day!) thus you can spend more time doing them over and over again, and ostensibly finish your gearing a bit faster than the raiding approach. iii) Craftables: All of the nice craftables require a metric shit-ton of materials. This boils down to money. You can take the obvious shortcut and just buy gold from your favorite gold-seller (which is, by the way, a clear violation of the terms of service and can warrant your account being permanently turned off), you can spend hours a week gathering the raw materials, or you can spend hours a week gathering different raw materials for someone else who is willing to pay you for your trouble and then use this money to obtain your new gear. It should be noted that, by and large, there are two ways to gather the right kinds of raw materials: Kill the same type of monster, over and over, or, ride around looking for dots on your map that correspond to some sort of gatherable raw material (fighting anyone and anything that might be in your way in the process). There are many who argue that i) and ii) take a modicum of skill. I beg to differ. They take a large dose of PRACTICE. Within weeks, if not days, of "new" content being released, the appropriate strategy for defeating every monster and boss in a dungeon or raid is available on the internet. Within a few months, even better strategies are out there, and at this point Blizzard begins to "nerf" the instances and bosses, significantly making them easier (or in Blizzard terms, "more accessible"). Most of the time then, unless you are one of the extremely few folks who truly "push" content by being the literal World First to down something new (which, by the way, means you have a nearly infinite supply of money to purchase all the in game materials to make the process doable), you will be following a strategy that someone else came up with. It may be tricky, you may have to practice - but it's all out there. Written down. Waiting for you to read and execute. A new raid zone is AWESOME, for the first few weeks, even with all this. Learning what to do, learning when to do it, and practicing the execution. But after that - it becomes another grind. The monsters and bosses in Warcraft are supremely predictable and dumb. They do not target healers, unless the tanks are failing at their job. They do not target the damage dealers, unless the tanks are failing at their job. Every single target eventually boils down to three things: Have it hit someone that is hard to kill, have the healers keep that someone alive, and have the damage dealers kill it. The mechanics waver and feature random bits of buggery to accomplish at times, and some fights (High King Maulgar comes to mind) require some unusual tanking assignments and a high degree of coordination to accomplish - but once you get it down, it's always the same. Always. Everything reacts in the same way. The only variability comes in when a spell or ability of one of the players is resisted, and a burst of chaos enters the scene for 5 or so seconds until things are brought back in line with the printed strategy that was memorized from the internet. Even those bosses which feature a defined random element (Archimonde's ray things, or Prince Malchezzars's infernals) either have "safe zones" that render the random element moot, or, with sufficient practice week after week, you zone out and react like a good little gaming puppet to the pseudo-randomness that there is. And then, once you have the rigors of memorization of your role out of the way, it's time to hope that the random chance table for the bosses affords a sufficiently varied result that most of the folks in your group get at least a few solid upgrades, so they can move on to the next ever-so-awesome raid, with its new strategies to memorize. Raiding, in turn, because of the grind that it is, generally boils down to a very simple equation: purples per hour. Folks will generally want to maximize this value: if it drops too low, they will leave your guild in search of greener (purpler?) pastures. And, as it turns out, the way to increase your purples per hour is to go to some of the very same internet sites that tell you how to do a given raid boss, and play your class just like they tell you. That's right. Others have already min-maxed the shit out of your class. Save yourself the trouble. Memorize, and execute, the correct talent specialization, obtain the recommended gear, push the buttons in the order described, download the appropriate user interface modification to simplify the process, and behold, you are at the top of your game. Congratulations. So to sum up, the major skills required to succeed and advance in Warcraft (as measured by the one metric of success and advancement, in game terms: better equipment): 1) Reading 2) Rote memorization 3) Mastery of your class' 2 or 3 "I win" buttons 4) Hiding behind pillars 5) Acquiring money 6) Finding friends, or at least people who will put up with you for a chance at better gear, who are at least as well-read as you are Skill-based gameplay, indeed. 3) Variety - or more accurately, the lack thereof. Warcraft features a modicum of customization options for your character. There are a total of five "axes" of variability. All races feature a common set of four: Hair Color, Hair Style, Face Shape, and Skin Tone. Each race has one additional option such as Tusks, Beards, Facial Tattoos, and so on. Each axis has around 8 options, in some cases, fewer. For the mathematically inclined, that comes out to a whopping 32,768 different possible . . .face/skin tone/hairstyle/hair color combination. Note that only the head is affected. In a given race, the actual visible SHAPE of the character is precisely the same. At first glance, all you will ever notice that is "different" is hair color and hair style - but if you take a good 20 or so male night elves and put them all in a row, you'd swear they were all the same person plus or minus some time with Clairol. In short it's very easy to look like a member of a very homogeneous army. Now compound this with the PVE or PVP grind described above. There is generally only 1 or 2 pieces of gear for any given slot on your character that you will want - these are the 'correct' pieces for your class and spec, and are of course described in detail on a variety of websites so you can discover how to get them. Which leads to . . the uniform. Every member of your class is after the same gear, most of the time. The net result? Once you have achieved the appropriate level of success in the game - you now look exactly like everyone else. Every priest that has Karazhan on "farm status" looks identical. Every rogue that has survived the travails of SerpentShrine Cavern for 6 months . . .looks identical. Every warrior who competes in the Arena System eventually looks identical. Thus, the very best you hope you can achieve (in game terms of equipment) . . is the appropriate uniform for that level of raiding or PVP experience. The ONLY exception to this, are absurdly rare items of legendary status, which, while there are almost always more than one per server, are rare enough you are lucky to see more than a half dozen over a few months. To have any hope of obtaining these items, you have to secure the buy-in of 20+ other folks that you and you alone will get them - or just get lucky on some loot rolls. And even with this, we're talking about one item per character - and they are all weapons at present. And even these amazing legendary items - have all been outclassed by follow-on raids in the first expansion. So even that hard-won (or lucked into) legendary weapon itself becomes another bank slot filler in a matter of a year or so, or less, depending on how efficient your personal purples-per-hour equation is. 4) Problem-solving? Who needs it! After my experience with Myst: Uru Online(game has now been cancelled, not sure how long that link will work), I can say with some confidence that a MMORPG that is NOTHING but puzzles fails to engage (at least folks like me) for very often. One or two days a month was sufficient. On the flip side, a MMORPG where there are NO puzzles at all and every encounter with anything always boils down to killing something(s) isn't all that engaging long term, either. The amount of brainpower required to reach the highest level in the game of Warcraft is somewhere around zero. You don't even have to read all those internetz sites. You can just wander aimlessly around hitting things until they stop moving until one day you're a 70. That's it. Granted, it will take longer than most folks, but you'll get there just on sheer patience if nothing else. Of course, you will have really crappy equipment and can't do the "end game" worth a damn, but you made it to the highest level of experience possible. Hell, there's even leveling guides you can go download off the internet that have an efficient path mapped out for you so you can even FURTHER unplug your mental circuitry. Now while almost every every RPG out there, pen and paper included, has this model of "kill stuff, get xp, advance", it is AWFULLY nice, in my estimation, to have something else to occupy your mind from time to time other than "what is the most efficient way to kill this person/bear/dragon/etc". While yes that can be fun, one of my continuing frustrations was, after spending a great deal of time plotting a path through a cave to get to a boss of some sort, and just when I have everything all situated and ready to be all tactical and awesome . . . some of the shit I already killed just mysteriously comes back and fucks it all up. One of the major "pacing" mechanics used in Warcraft is the fact that nothing ever really dies - it just vanishes for a period of time and then returns. But back to my point - even the one real brain-teaser type puzzle that does exist (how do I accomplish this quest by myself with my non-awesome equipment) is usually rendered moot because either due to class or gear you can't actually kill stuff fast enough to accomplish it. Beyond that, there's nothing. There's some cool (and all-too-few in my estimation) pseudo-Indiana Jones moments (such as the lights in the Temple of Atal'Hakkar) .. but that's it. Most of the game is just killing stuff in a new way, or in a new place. There's no puzzles to solve, no codes to crack, no locks to pick (well, there are, but it's done like a spell - just hit a button and it works or not), no documents to translate (at least not by you - there are a few errand quests where you run stuff around so someone else can do all the fun parts to it while you play Mr. Gatti's Delivery Boy for 13 silver), no lore to go hunt for in a library, etc. While I grant that not everyone wants to use their brain while they are gaming, and even I did have days where I actually looked FORWARD to logging in and killing a few hundred whatever-they-weres just for the mental vacation, I am very much of the opinion that the game is severely lacking in any elements that challenges the intellect. And after a very long time, that lack has really just started to wear on me. It's like I am an assembly-line worker of death dealing and loot harvesting. So there they are, the Big Four. Lack of variety, lack of having a chance to impact the world, lack of encounters or events requiring intelligence, lack of player skill development. Warcraft has become one giant quest for better gear, with nothing else really going for it. I have dabbled with the thought of rolling on a PVP server - only to find out once you hit 61 or so it's a giant gank fest in Outland by the path you can get to it and questing becomes well-nigh impossible, I have rolled on an RP server - only to find out 90% of the folks there don't RP and a good half of those make fun of the RP'ers, and I have rolled on a PVP-RP server but at this point I'm sure it will converge on the first two styles pretty rapidly. And even on an RP server - the level of belief suspension necessary to negotiate the fact that hey, it's time to clear that dungeon again since it mysteriously repopulated itself . . . well it all sort of breaks down doesn't it. I mean if the Scarlet Crusade really did have an infinite supply of level 40 or so folks in the Monastery, why is there ANYTHING left alive in Tirisfal Glades? You'd think by any rational stretch they'd just overrun it all. It leads to a kind of "stasis field" around your character: each day is exactly like the previous one and you just replay it over and over, like a video game version of Groundhog Day. I don't know what my MMORPG future holds. There are not many to choose from for us Mac-heads at the moment. At the very least, this experience has a) gained me several good friends and b) taught me what I need to look for in future MMORPG's that might interest me and my wife. In the final analysis, I'm glad I played. It opened up new doors for me and was damned fun for a very, very long time. I actually will still encourage folks to try it out - I mean come on, I got 3 years of joy out of it. I can't really deny that kind of thing to anyone :)

I'm here at work just sitting giddy. I inherited a sex-appeal filled iMac from a co-worker today (Scot, for those who know all these people), to replace my aged but still moderatly useful 2003 vintage PPC Dual G4 tower. That old machine has been bequeathed to Ismael, who has been jonesing for a Mac for some time now. BUT this new one I've got - wowzers but it's pretty. Has the glossy screen, a whopping 24", and thus dwarfs the 20" monitor I had before. Well, to be fair, I had TWO 20" monitors. Now down to just one, that I have set to rotate 90˚ and thus provides a nice tall vertical screen for reading. I've gone apeshit with Spaces and have things set to different places so it all makes sense (workspace 1, for example, is email/personal journaling, while workspace 2 is for web surfing), with the IM and iTunes clients on all workspaces so I can always get to me friends and tunes. I've had a spate of organizational furor of late, trying to get my workplace into some semblance of usability. I'm hopeful this new machine and the subsequent dorking out will provide further motiviation. Snagging some cheap yet pretty desktop organizers for the shit-ton of pens and crap I had isn't hurting either :)

I was listening to NPR yesterday and caught a Bush II quote I have been able to ascertain was not taken all that out of context. I don't have the exact quote but it was something along the lines of "congress needs to sign legislation to authorize oil and natural gas exploration in American territories". What? You fucking dunderhead, what did you ask for? Searching for more oil and gas is not a positive, forward looking solution. It is a backward, regressive, retrograde, pat Big Oil on the back political maneuver. It is full of fail. The reason oil prices (and thus gas prices) are high is a very simple, very elementary rule of economics: supply and demand. The supply, by any rational measure, hasn't gone down (yet). The demand has sharply increased over the past few years, particularly as nations like China and India continue to plow into the industrial revolution for their countries. Yes, you can help adjust those prices via increasing the supply - but!!! 1) Finding new supplies of any significant size in America is unlikely 2) Even if it is found it will not be brought on line and producing oil for years 3) Once its found kiss whatever natural environment it was found in goodbye and instead greet your new roads and clearcuts and removed mountaintops and smelly air from petroleum processing plants with a great big Bush-Hug. 4) And after all that - the supply of oil is FINITE. It WILL run OUT someday. This means to me we need to fix the DEMAND side of the problem. Granted, Republicans are notorious for ignoring the demand side of the economical equation (supplyside is the best side! wee!). But let's be realistic here. The best path for our tax dollars is not to fund more oil exploration, or funding the lollipop handouts of a reduced gas tax, or funding yet another war in Iran so we can try to take over their oil reserves since we failed to do so in Iraq, or cobbling together some vastly misguided and stupid approach to use food crops (like corn) to make a gas substitute (like ethanol) - the BEST path is to fund RESEARCH. Omg he said the 'R' word. Consider that in 1961 Kennedy called on Congress to put a man on the moon by the end of the decade. They managed to do it. And they did it for a suprisingly small pile of cash, particularly considering what our current US budget is. What Bush II needs to be extorting Congress to do is not fund yet more hunting for a natural resource that we'll eventually run out of regardless of what we do, he needs to be exhorting Congress (and yes I swapped words intentionally there) to fund research on renewable energy sources. A good goal would be "eliminate all gas consumption on American roads by 2020". There is no reason at this point we're still using gas to power our cars - except that it's cheap, easy, and keeps the current rich folks rich. If America's fuel consumption dropped to 0, that right there would dramatically lower our dependence on foreign oil, and keep MORE of that oil around LONGER to deal with the other petroleum crisis - our growing dependence on plastics. Look around - I bet most of the stuff in arms reach has oil in it somewhere. That has further impacts on the medical industry - vast amounts of medical supplies are made of plastic of one form or another. Plastic is what concerns me, and the more oil we can keep around to cover that while we figure out what the fuck to do about replacing it is FAR more important than keeping 20mpg cars on the road. Stop using gas is too hard? Damn right it's hard. Hell of a lot of work involved in that. Public transportation would have to improve. Car manufactures would have to swap over to new technologies. The RV in its current form would be abolished. New forms of energy would have to be developed and mass-produced (fuel cell, solar, biomass, etc). Lots of current businesses would be hit, and hit hard. Along with that entire new growth sectors would crop up. New car companies. New energy utilities. A whole slew of burgeoning companies moving to exploit the new technologies. THIS is what capitalism is supposed to be about - innovation and exploration, not grinding a deeper rut in the road because of fear and risk aversion. At the moment, I'm thoroughly disgusted. Perhaps our next President might be a bit more motivational, but I am starting to doubt these trends in America will be reversed until it's just plain too late.

In my quest to find opportunities to express my creativity without having to spend a crapton of money, along with my repeatedly surfacing interest in fantasy, both roleplaying and writing (yes writing!), I'm going to attempt to accomplish a project that has been bouncing around inside my head for years but, due to lack of the right tools, lack of time, and lack of motivation I have thus far made zero progress. Now that warcraft is fading as a major presence in my life, I have freed up a good 20 or 30 hours a week of time - so there's the time, at least. The next step is to see if I have the proper motivation to hammer on something slighly monolithic in scope and that also has zero instant gratification potential ;) part of the crack that is Warcraft is the fact you can actually accomplish "significant" (based on the measurements of the game, at least) things in a relatively short amount of time, unlike other things such as, for example, real life. The new project is to, quite simply, design a world. The intent is to do the whole picture - everything from the broadest scope of the shape of the continents, down to the details of the names of pubs in at least some of the larger townships. I also hope to do this using zero proprietary software, throwing my fate to the winds of the OpenSource community. This means the cost is zero :) For the text portion of this work I intend to learn TeX, the rendering language for text that has taken off from somewhere and is now becoming a standard for things like books, disserations, and so forth. I find it somewhat amusing that this represents a full circle move for me - the very first word processor I ever used was BankStreet Writer, and as I recall in that application you typed in your text and then put markers around the parts you wanted to be bolded, or bigger, or whatever. Next was WordPerfect, which operated similarly - you were presented with a blue screen of text, the text was different colors on your display depending on what the text would look like when you printed it. It was impossible to know what your document looked like, until you printed it, in fact. Then BOOM along comes MicroSoft and so forth, and the EoTWE was born - the "Era of the WYSIWYG Editor". And that was all the hot shit for a time. Well now we're with TeX, which is not WYSIWYG - in fact to see your document at all you have to "render" it, much as you'd have to render a webpage if you coded it up in straight HTML. However, this approach affords the author infinite control over a document, as nothing is done automatically. It also permits a very strict adherence to whatever style you wish to use - no more guessing as to what font to use for Section Headings, for example. There is no annoying paperclip popping up every five minutes with a "say it looks like you are trying to write a document. Here, let me write that for you". And it's utterly, completely cross platform as the files you save out are, I believe, some form of XML and so long as you have a TeX renderer available for your machine, you've got the document. This is somewhat easier than you'd think - as since TeX is opensource from the ground up and has been around for over a decade there is a metric crapton of support for it out there on just about every platform. For the graphics work, I have two paths forward. I'd prefer to go the vector graphics version, because, on the off chance this work should ever become some sort of final product, it would be nice to have all the maps and associated drawings in a digital format that can be re-used, scaled, and otherwise fiddled with in a very predictable and consistent manner. Bitmap graphics, while pretty and all, really don't support that kind of work. Secondly, using some sort of standard that is supported by a variety of tools is a good idea for maximum portability, so I don't have to convert it all to something else later. About five minutes of research on the InTernEtZ located not one, but two tools which accomplish this - Inkscape and Xara. Both are open source, both have many features, both are actively being worked on. I chose Inkscape, at least for the first go-round, because it is not affiliated with a for-profit software company (Xara opensource is a subset of a for-sale item of a similar name) because hey, it's my project, I can make fickle decisions like that. So the immediate tasks before me is to learn two radically new tools, which is nice, because I like learning new things :) Meanwhile I updated my picture, due to a request from Dawn who pointed out I've not had that rich full head of hair in years now. The new one features a more current picture of me, sipping on a spot of Earl Gray I brewed up this morning. The room is my current home office.

Setting up ye olde new laptop atm (scored an apple powerbook for work, so I can work at home. While not an ideal situation in general, it does provide a laptop to putter around with crap in the house, which is a nice feature :) As a work laptop, there are certain rules I abide by so as to not raise stress and issues - for example, no one else is ever allowed to use it, I maintain a screenlock password on it, I will never install any bittorrent like application on it (a protocol expressly forbidden in our workplace), and so forth. Nevertheless: IT'S a FUCKING AWESOME LAPTOP!! . . which now has a fresh copy of iJournal on it :D

So work has been a bitch but I'll skip all that for now.  I'm home puttering on my machine and getting things a little neater in my home space.  The missus came up with some AWESOMESAUCE ideas for general home adjustment and re-arrangment and my mind has wandered off on that for a bit today as well.

Core issue stems from the fact that we're at a bit of a cross-roads - do we spend money fixing up this house, or spend money buying a new one?  Both options are pricey - we've got some fundamental shit wrong with the home at this point, ranging from leaks around poorly sealed roof penetrations to needing a coat of paint on the outside to a potentially severe case of internal wood rot under the toilet in the upstairs bathroom.

I want a bluetooth keyboard.

Sorry random aside.  We also need a new refrigerator, a new HVAC, and a new roof.  Gonna be a pricey year indeed.  However, I'm sort of of the opinion that staying here and making it work may prove to be the more economical solution over the next 5  years or so, particularly with the cratering of the housing market.  Granted, we could now get more house than we have for substantially the same amount of money - but selling our current property could be tricksy.  Plus some of our home expenses at least are knowns - and a new home is all unknowns.  My core financial concerns stem from the fact that in 8 years we will need to either have or be able to acquire some $250K for Alasen's trip to college, give or take.  There are also new concerns with insurance - some companies are now requiring their patients to pay a percentage of their prescriptions, and if that carries over to Dawn's semi-monthly treatments, and it's not capped, we're looking at $48K/year cost to consider as well - which is just untenable. 

Which means we'll give the bird to corporate America and bail for Europe where her condition constitutes a disability and we can use a national healthcare system besides.

As far as the post title:  Unbeknownst to me Seth wandered off and found me a replacement for one of my "raids" I was involved in in World of Warcraft, all because I mentioned to him once the roster was done I was moving on.  What a sweety :) 

MY SUNDAY NIGHTS ARE MINE AGAIN!

So on my very next attempt to use IJournal it crapped out and crashed. So fooey on that, now trying Xjournal, which is of course a) beta and b) open source so God only knows if it will work for the next 10 minutes or not. In any event I think I have successfully completed whoring myself out to every social network service known to man - I can now be found at Facebook, Shelfari, MySpace, and Virb, as well as the venerable LiveJournal for those of you seeing this . .not on LiveJournal. Of course, MySpace is the only one of those that does not have a blog import feature to slurp up all this exciting writing straight from LiveJournal, but then MySpace has always pretty much been kinda poopular in my estimation as far as stability and features go. However, I have a metric crapton of friends there so I will be endeavoring to at least post a link, if not a full cross post, of blog entries to that amalgamated mass of internet content. It's now 2:36am and I'm hoping to feel tired at some point. Having had an EXTREMELY long day yesterday (Friday) of some 17 work hours, and then sleeping till 10ish this morning followed by another 4 hours of work, I'm puzzled as to my lack of fatigue, but hey, what can you do. Might as well putter on ye olde computer, I suppose :)

So at long last I am (again) attempting to maintain some state of a virtual online presence and community via blogging as well as joining a frightful pile of social networking sites in a feeble attempt to keep up with my wife who manages to somehow be everywhere at once, at least on the internet :)  This post is also serving as a test for my automatic blog updating tool, which hopefully will work satisfactorily . . . .

So the Men's Retreat was last weekend, as I alluded to in my previous somewhat depressive posts (and sorry hon for referring to you as a material possession, that was a grammatical oversight induced by lumping you in the category of "stuff that makes me happy" - of which you are a large part ;)

I feel MUCH better.  My initial whines about "waa job" and "waaa death" and "waa blah blah blah blah" were pretty much out of the way and shut down the first night. Being with 20 odd other men ranging in age from mid 20's to upper 60's+ reallllly puts things in perspective as far as careers and retirement goes.

Saturday I did something I've not gotten a chance to do in a very long time - I went for a walk. ALONE.  IN THE MIDDLE OF NOWHERE.

I was off for over an hour, just me, my thoughts, and random cacti I thought looked interesting.  The ranch we were at was fairly large, so I just picked a direction and headed out.  I was reminded during this journey just how important and necessary for me personal space really is.  I NEED time to myself, away from ALL social distractions.  I haven't been alone like this in several months now, as between a job, a family, and a video game that generally involves some social interaction, such opportunities are very rare.  Dawn and I have already talked about this and she too recognizes my  need for this type of time, so I do believe we will make sure that I get some of it on occasion.

That's the one most impressive thing about our releationship, I think, above all the other happy shit in it - we communicate, listen, and adjust things and work out things exceptionally well.

Somewhere in the weekend I found my Zen back . . . I used to have it with me all the time but over the past few years it sort of slipped away.  My Zen, for me, comprises a state of mind, a relaxation, a lack of fear, a comfort with the universe, a warm feeling of belonging, of the flow of water that finds its way down stream regardless of eddies, rapids, dams, etc - it makes it somewhere, even if it gets sidetracked along the way.

And to top it all off . . . I had one of those "DUH" moments.  As some of you may know I have all these side interests - computer art/animation, writing, music making, etc.  I have felt very concerned that come my demise I was going to look back on my life and say "well shit I didn't get ANYTHING DONE".  No books written, no cd's recorded, etc.  This was leaving me with a vague sense of guilt.  That's right, I was feeling guilty and stressed out about shit I hadn't done yet.  I filed this under "extremely stupid" :)

One of the other attendees passed on a bit of wisdom - "Worry is the interest you pay on stress you don't have  yet".  I keep that one close to my heart now - only worry about the real stuff, not about the hypothetical stuff.

So Saturday night I stayed up and had a good long talk with myself.  What, exactly, did I really want to do before I died?  What would be the main things to see, so that I could pass on to the next world and/or cease to be satisfied with my time here?  I am pleased to report, the final list was actually pretty short, and didn't have a lot of stuff I really figured would have been on it.

My list:

1)  See Europe
2)  See Australia
3)  See New Zealand
4)  See Melissa S. and Suzi S. naked

Clearly, number 4 may get altered as we all age, but for now they are the two women I've met that I really do have some wistful desire at seeing nude - and artfully nude mind you, I am not out to hump them or use them in some sordid sexual show or whathaveyou.

So rolling into Monday then, my overall attitude toward life, the universe, and everything was much improved.  Work is now not some damned obstacle fucking up my life . . it's just work.  I go to work to make money to allow for other things in my life.  Each day I will do what I feel like doing, and do what I have to do to survive, and that's it.  No more "waaah no time for X" or "waaaa I didn't get a chance to do Y".  Fuck all that.  It's now Wednesday and I still feel the same :)  hell I've even started puttering in the garage and getting it cleaned up instead of rushing home to escape to Warcraft.  But of course when I'm done puttering in the garage I go log into Warcraft - because it's fun, and I enjoy it.  Not because, as I was very dangerous to feeling last week - it's the ONLY fun I have in my life, but because it's "hey, that sounds good, I'll go do that for a bit".

Speaking of fun, time for lunch.  Ta ta!

Ended up at an odd conclusion today at the office while engaged in a pseudo-psychological exchange with a coworker. He was expressing frustration at the backsliding of America back to the point where science and technology take 2nd chair to mythology and religion. I took that to the final point of "By then we'll be in the midst of a nuclear winter, because both sides will say their God will protect them from the missiles launched by the devils across the sea". I put together in my mind then that, evoluntarily speaking, we have the seeds of our own destruction inside of us - fear of the fact (or at least the possibility) of the futility of life leads to religion - which then leads to an accelerated demise of our species. This then led me back to a train of thought I wander down from time to time: I take as a given that life is pretty much meaningless, an afterlife, if it is present at all, will have very little to do with my current life, and that my existence in this corporeal, conscious form is about all I, as a human, will ever know. For the depressive, this may well lead to "what's the point, might as well kill myself". For me however I've taken that ball and run the other way: "I only get one trip around, might as well have as much fucking fun as I possibly can". But if I truly believe that, why do I remain in a lifestlye and career that I find unstimulating? What drives me to remain at the same 40 hour a week job that I will never be fabulously wealthy at? Usually I end up with some sort of risk/reward analysis. I work now so I can play later. The downside of that of course, is, what if later never comes? What if I make it to retirement age, still have my health and a few million dollars, and then get shot or hit by a car or any of a number of random events that every one of us is only missing by inches every day. Alternatively, if I just did exactly what I wanted right this very moment for every moment, I would lose my house, my girl, my computer, my car - basically every material thing that I use for pleasure or enjoyment. If I had nothing but the clothes I wear now, I would be BORED OUT OF MY MIND. Hard to write a novel if you can't even afford to purchase paper. Obviously my forays into World of Warcraft would be over. This whole set of reasoning is why I always hate questions like "if today was the last day you would live, what would you do?" or "what would you do if you had a million dollars" that are somehow supposed to assess your current happiness level and/or what you should do with your life. They are bullshit. Any rational person has to make plans and attend to trivialities that will bite you in the ass (random example: dental work) if you don't. If it's your last day on the planet, the last damned thing you'd be doing is taking out the trash or paying bills or going to work. Fuck that, you'd be out whoring it up or doing drugs or stealing cars or flying to Europe or whatever. The balance comes in having at least SOME fun everyday, and I need to reassert that goal for myself. Of late it's been too easy to just do crap I have to do, and not as much of what I'd like to do, and I'm beginning to suspect perhaps that's part of my frustration and depression that has sort of settled on me. Somewhat lifted last night by a viewing of Mary Poppins and Lola Rennt, two very uplifting movies that remind you that hey, there's good out there to enjoy along with whatever crap you choose to focus on and be negative about. Yesterday I came home and did NOTHING for a solid 20 minutes. I sat on my ass, let the cats wander by, and dozed. Not even a focussed nap, it was truly nothing. It was awesome. Tonight I get to play Warcraft. This weekend is a retreat. Next week, more warcraft, movies, and FUN, dammit!

So this weekend I'm going on my first ever "Church Men's Retreat". My church is Live Oak Unitarian Universalist Church, a fine little place that does the usual batch of potlucks and coffee time post service, along with gay weddings and the biggest list of committees this side of Congress. I've been active at various levels over the years, though of late my level has dropped off somewhat because I am on my 2nd year of teaching Sunday School and Dawn is finally getting back on her treatments for Gaucher's, a particularly nasty little hereditary enzymatic deficiency syndrome, which, since it only affects like, 6 people in the country and is thus not profitable to do anything about it's not all that easy to get taken care of. So between her health levels dropping a bit and the stress involved of actually GETTING the treatments going, plus my own waffling enjoyment of my existence at times I only have so much bandwidth to dedicate to others these days. But hey if I vote Republican all my worries will be taken care of, right? Right? But anyway. So this weekend is my first ever "Retreat" of pretty much any kind, particularly one relating to church. I'm looking forward to it, actually. It will take me away from home for TWO WHOLE DAYS and the focus topic is one that has been in the back of my mind for a while now - "Moving Through Time". Mortality. Sex. Wisdom gains and losses. That kind of big heady stuff (hopefully mixed in a with a big dose of 4 wheeling and beer). I'm 35 next year. By most estimates, that's about halfway to my death, if not more than (thanks for the great genes, Mom and Dad, yessir, diabetes and heart disease, oh boy!). I have at least twenty more years of work before I can retire with any real hope of financial security for myself and my family, and given the trend these days I'm thinking that will end up being much closer to 30 years from now. I work a job that uses my brain, so my rest time usually means NOT using my brain - which is a real cockblock when it comes to pursuing brain intensive things that I'd LIKE to be doing, like writing and music making. There's also the growing realization that any dreams or goals I had of ever making "history" in any meaningful way need to be pretty much chucked out the door. Statistically my best years, brain wise, are behind me, and I'll be lucky to get a couple novels published before I kick the bucket. So the NON depressive side of all that then is what, exactly, do I do to maximize my FUN in the time I have left. When you don't believe in heaven, there's no safety net of "oh, but Heaven will be great, I'll work here and play there". I need play time. Alasen will be on her way to college in about 10 years, which is at present the one big financial obligation I feel we are faced with as a family, we need to get her ready and get her prepared so she has the opportunity to make choices about her life - the kind of choices that I had access to and that I and Dawn want her to have. Once that's done and she's off being healthy and pursuing (hopefully) lucrative interests that will set her up (and, God willing, she doesn't end up pregnant and pro-life along the way botching all that to hell) for the rest of her life, that allows Dawn and I to examine real choices as far as where WE want to go, what WE want to do, and see, and visit, and live in. We've dabbled with the idea of moving out of the country, but I don't see that as a real possibility before Alasen is in college, if for no other reason than simple economics. So I do have a lot to look forward to from about 46 until death, and I should be reasonably healthy at that age that I will even enjoy it :) but the hard part for me now is slogging through the next 10 years without getting despondent about it. Fortunately for me, Dawn is a continual source of light and hope in my life, and Alasen - well Alasen teaches me how to be a kid again :) So. This weekend a nice retreat dealing with issues that plague my mind about the future of my life :) Clearly a great deal of a person's happiness is determined by how they choose to perceive it, mixed in with a matching of expectations to reality. I am looking forward to this retreat for a chance at perspectives from others who am I sure have grappled on some level with these same questions. Huzzah! Back to staring at documentation.

Well, at least for my druid :) After braving the flames of Sulfuron and suffering the "Last Service for Ragnaros" and countless deaths, repair bills, and expensive potions, Elondra Mistrunner, Level 60 Druid on Blackhand server, has "graduated" from the Molten Core. I went in with no epic gear at all, and have come out with 13. The original wishlist was 16, so for an 8 month or so run I've done pretty well. Just don't have the patience to deal with the remaining 4-6 months it would probably be for the remaining 3. So she moves on now to the "next" raiding instance, Blackwing Lair. We're doing that two nights a week now, for the time being, for a total of about 11 hours/week in this one place. We will eventually get it down to one night a week, of probably around 6 hours, but . . this is just how it's done :) these place are huge and time consuming. Draedeyn, along with his betrothed Myraehn (played by my "real life" honey Dawn) now steps into the Molten Core primarily to assist in keeping things going - these places take 40 folks to run successfully, particuarly in the early stages when everyone is still learning, and we represent two essential classes for the moment. I don't really MIND going back on a different character, Dawn however hates the place, so we are looking for eventual replacements so we can go do something else more fun - like Ahn'Qiraj or Zul'Gurub. We stay in MC for the moment out of loyalty - we have several friends there and don't want them left in the lurch just because a few folks aren't available. The analogy I've started using to explain raiding obligations (to fend off the usual "OMG you SCHEDULE your time in a FUCKING VIDEO GAME Jesus you're a LOSER" commentary) is that this is basically a team sport (albeit a sedentary one). If you, say, like to play football or rugby or somesuch, you have a team, and you have to show up to practice. You don't show up to practice, or you lose your teammates, the games don't happen and nobody has any fun. MMORPG's are different in that respect - unlike, say, playing Zelda for an hour or two on a Saturday morning every once in a while, in a MMORPG once you have sort of established yourself people actually start to need you, or at least hope that you are available for things, and if you don't schedule your time to be available you rapidly sort of fall off the map and, depending on where your interests lie for your character anyway, start having less fun. Warcraft has been a very large experiment for me, being as it's my first MMORPG, and I'm still enjoying it, even coming up now on my 2nd year in game (started in February of '05). To date it is my longest lived hobby :) Though, granted, it does eat up an awful lot of time. I did reinstall Reason last night, as I'd like to start making music again. I probably won't drag out my huge MIDI keyboard just yet, as there's really not room for it, and we're too short on funds to go running out to buy something smaller - but I'm hopeful I can make do with the dragging around of notes for the time being. Finances are VERY tight at the moment, between pending wedding expenses, car debt, credit card debt, house payments, upcoming holidays, trips, etc etc etc - current target is that we can start actually spending money again sometime in 2011. That is one nice benefit of Warcraft for me - I have immense fun at around a dime an hour, with no travel costs incurred.

So yesterday the house passed the new bill regarding some redefinitions of torture, and some stuff about how to handle detainees, and how we can suspend habeus corpus, all that good stuff, you know, so we can . . .. I dunno, kill terrorists faster, or something. But the real jewel in this is apparently this new legislation (expected to pass the Senate today) will ALSO permit the delcaration of American Citizens as "enemy combatants". Which are nice weasel words used by our current duly elected President and his fine collection of officials to avoid the prohibitions outlined by the Geneva Conventions, since they only affect "prisoners of war". Some of you may recall, and some may not even know, that the designation of 'enemy combatant' is not a crime, nor is it a charge for arrest - it just means they can take you in and beat the crap out of you and hook electrodes to your body and flush your bible down the toilet, all that good stuff, and you get no phone call, no lawyer, no nothing. You MIGHT be allowed to face a military tribunal for your "crime", but of course they are under no obligation to share with you and/or the attorney you are not allowed to have any evidence they may be considering. Those of you in the Bush camp likely think all this is an exaggeration. That's fine, please return to your shell, put your fingers back in your ears, your head up your ass, and continue singing "lalalalalalala". Meanwhile, the rest of you - I'm fucking scared. There is NO legal recourse out of this designation, and even the paper thin veil of "well, they won't do THAT to American Citizens" no longer applies. At this point I still consider it likely, in about 10 or 20 years, that this legislation will be overturned by a less stacked supreme court - but how many Americans, I wonder, will be conveniently "dissappeared" in the meanwhile? How can anyone be comfortable at night if even the POSSIBILITY of such dissappearment exists? Power, once granted by the public to a specific office or collection of officials, is extremely difficult to take back. The 'checks and balances' are supposed to help mitigate such mistakes - but even they are slowly being eroded and have been so pretty much ever since the two party system came into being. Meanwhile the GOP is saying that 'Democrats are trying to give rights to Terrorists'. Without addressing that comment directly and the flaws in it, I would answer the GOP with "The Republicans are trying to take away constitutionally gauranteed rights from Americans".

So got to musing some this weekend while 3 7-9 year olds were running around being crappy to each other and just generally young - juxtaposed with an itchy anus I've been dealing with for some time now (no, don't have worms and yes, I'm clean).

Behold:

<u>The Cycle of Ages</u>

Newborn:  Waaah! Something itches!
Infant:  Waaah! My ass itches!!!!
Young Child:  Ass itches.  Scratch it.
Tween:  Ass itches.  Scratch it when my parents aren't looking.
Teen:  Ass itches.  Scratch it when my friends aren't looking.
Young Adult:  HAHAHA I live on my own I'm scratching my ass!
Single Adult:  Man my ass itches.  Guess I need to shower.
Married Adult:  Ass itches.  Scratch it when the spouse isn't looking.
Parent:  Ass itches.  Scratch it when the kids aren't looking.
Older Adult:  Ass itches.  Fuck you, I'm scratching it.
Middle Aged Adult:  My ass itches, but the doctor won't let me scratch it.
Elderly:  Hmmm.  My ass itches.  Sure wish I could scratch it, but I can't reach it anymore.
Senile:  Waaah! Something itches!

Having just caught up on my sweet honey's bwog, I realized something . . 

I NEVER ANNOUNCED MY ENGAGEMENT IN MY LIVEJOURNAL.

Presumably if this is to be a relatively up to date blog one would expect me to say such things.

So yea.  I proposed.  She accepted.  It was while we were having sex on the hood of my car in the driveway during a thunderstorm.

Well, that would have been ideal, I suppose.  As it was, we had arms full of leftovers and were in the process of moving the sprinkler.  All quite domestic, and VERY much US :D

I am ecstatically happy about it :)

Well there we have it. After . . several pointed pokes by the missus concluding with the "Honey, I'm there, many of your friends should be there, do this" message of this morning, I have GONE AND DONE IT. I have created a NEW myspace page, linked to the PROPER email address, that I will now monitor much as I monitor other things (but more frequently than I blog). I'm over at this spot. Even found one of my favorite songs to add to my profile.
